Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Designer nanostructures in protection of cells under harsh environment

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: This research focuses on the science behind developing nano rare earth particles and their role in the protection of cells under radiation environments. Potential payoffs include (1) engineering of nanoparticle surfaces for biomedical applications, (2) understanding and simulating the interaction of nanoparticles under harsh radiation atmospheres and (3) the use of nanoparticles in the prevention of radiation induced damage. The work tests the hypothesis that cerium oxide nanoparticles (CNPs) protect gastrointestinal mucosa from radiation therapy (RT) without protecting the tumor. This will be a major breakthrough in cancer treatment if it is successful. Project scope includes the synthesis and characterization of bare and polymer coated CNPs, numerical modeling of the nanoparticle-cell relationship to study the prevention of radiation damage by nanoceria, and determining the effect of CNPs on irradiated gastrointestinal mucosa and tumor in vitro. Broader impacts of the work are focused on biomedical applications and potential applications of nanotechnology to cancer treatment. The research will be integrated into various courses taught at the University. Both undergraduate and graduate students will be trained in this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Preventing healthy cells and killing the tumor cells is central to any cancer therapy. The objective of this research was to develop nano-rare earth particles (e.g., Nanoceria) for protection of healthy cells under radiation environment and to study the fate and implication of nanoparticles under intense radiation. The key importance of this research is to show using molecular dynamics simulation the effect of high energy radiation on the dynamic modification of nanoparticle surfaces and their implication in a biological system. We further tested the efficacy of the Nanoceria in cancer cells under high dose gamma rays, where the cancer cells were effectively destroyed while protecting the healthy cells. Variation in free radical scavenging by cerium oxide nanoparticles as a function of radiation dosage is documented. It is postulated that the surface valence states of the nanoparticle play a key role in free radical scavenging. As a model system, the effect of radiation on the oxidation state of Ce in high-quality single and polycrystalline ceria thin films is studied. Molecular dynamics simulation of thermal spikes and displacement cascade damage provide details of radiation induced defects at the end of the range of the ions that can contribute to the observed reduction in the cerium oxide. Broader impact - In the event of any radiological disaster, these nanoparticles can be used as novel radio protective agents.
